content:
• Tuesday, July 19, 2016
  • PGNX

    FDA OKs oral Relistor for OIC in adults

    • RELISTOR (methylnaltrexone bromide) developer Progenics Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:PGNX) is up 7% after hours on increased volume in response to the news that the FDA has approved an oral formulation of the medicine that is indicated for the treatment of opioid-induced constipation in adults with chronic non-cancer pain.
    • The FDA approved the injectable formulation in April 2008.
    • Exclusive licensee Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) is up 3% after hours on robust volume, mainly from the positive Ad Comm vote for brodalumab.
    • Read now Progenics: Key FDA Decision Could Power This Under $5 Biopharma Stock 
     
     
     
     
    | 6:30 PM | 55 Comments
  • CTAS

    Cintas higher after FQ4 earnings beat, above consensus FY 2017 guidance

    • Cintas (NASDAQ:CTAS) +3.2% AH after beating FQ4 earnings expectations and reporting an 11% Y/Y revenue increase to $1.27B, sparked by its main uniform rental and facility services segment which posted growth despite the energy sector downturn.
    • CTAS issues above consensus guidance for FY 2017, seeing EPS of $4.35-$4.45 vs. $4.30 analyst consensus estimate on revenues of $5.15B-$5.225B vs. $5.17B consensus.
    • In FQ4, operating income margin improved to 16% from 15.6% of revenue in the year-ago quarter.
    • For the full fiscal year, CTAS posted EPS from continuing operations of $4.09, up from $3.46 the year before, and revenue rose 9.6% Y/Y to $4.91B.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:16 PM
  • ZFGN

    Zafgen dumps beloranib for second-generation obesity candidate; cuts 34% of workforce; shares crater 42% after hours

    • Beaten down micro cap Zafgen (NASDAQ:ZFGN) delivers another gut shot to shareholders with its announcement that it is abandoning lead product candidate beloranib in favor of ZGN-1061, a second-generation MetAP2 inhibitor it says is a better obesity candidate because its highly differentiated properties reduce the risk of thrombosis, an unwanted connection that sunk beloranib. Management made its decision based on the excessive cost and lengthy development timeline to continue with beloranib.
    • The company is currently screening patients to initiate a Phase 1 study assessing the safety, tolerability and weight loss efficacy of ZGN-1061 over four weeks of treatment. Results should be available by late Q1 2017. If all goes well, it will advance ZGN-1061 to later-stage development for the treatment of severe and complicated obesity.
    • In connection with its new strategy, Zafgen will cut 31 employees (34% of headcount) by year end, saving $4.8M per annum in workforce expenses once fully implemented. It will record a $2.4M non-recurring charge this quarter related to the downsizing. President Patrick Loustau and Chief Commercial Officer Alicia Secor will also be departing.
    • The FDA shut down the late-stage study evaluating beloranib in December 2015 after a second patient died from thrombosis-related issues.
    • Shares are down 42% after hours on robust volume.
    • Previously: Zafgen down further after hours as complete clinical hold ordered (Dec. 2, 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 6:13 PM | 11 Comments

  • HAWK

    Blackhawk Network Holdings beats by $0.13, revenue in-line

    • Blackhawk Network Holdings (NASDAQ:HAWK): Q2 EPS of $0.37 beats by $0.13.
    • Revenue of $183.7M (+9.9% Y/Y) in-line.
    • Shares +4.7% AH.

  • PRI

    Primerica slides; SA author says Ackman targeted wrong MLM

    • Primerica (PRI -6.4%) will collapse before Herbalife, says SA contributor The Friendly Bear in a Pro article published this morning.
    • "Between the DOL fiduciary rule and Friday’s Herbalife settlement from the FTC, we think there is almost no chance that Primerica’s MLM structure can survive through 2018."
    • The stock, he says, is the most asymmetric situation he's ever seen, with 70% downside, zero long-term upside, and real potential of the stock going to zero.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:33 PM | 42 Comments
  • ISRG

    Intuitive Surgical Q2 top line up 14%; net income up 37%; shares ahead 5% after hours

    • Intuitive Surgical (NASDAQ:ISRG) Q2 results ($M): Total Revenues: 670.1 (+14.3%); Instruments And Accessories: 339.3 (+14.3%); Systems: 202.7 (+15.2%); Services: 128.1 (+13.1%).
    • Net Income: 184.5 (+37.2%); Non-GAAP Net Income: 220.4 (+27.5%); EPS: 4.71 (+32.3%); Non-GAAP EPS: 5.62 (+23.0%).
    • Da Vinci shipments: 15 (+200.0%).
    • Shares are up 5% after hours on increased volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:21 PM | 2 Comments
  • MRCC

    Monroe Capital lower on capital raise

    • The size of the secondary offering isn't disclosed. Proceeds will be used to pay down debt and invest in portfolio companies.
    • MRCC -4.2% after hours

  • ESV

    Ensco signs contracts, sells six rigs for scrap

    • Ensco (ESV -4.9%) has sold off six assets for scrap and signed new short-term contracts but also was hit by a contract cancellation, according to its latest fleet status report.
    • ESV says Japan’s Marubeni exercised its right to terminate its contract early, effective in August, for the Ensco 8505 semisubmersible, which was operating at a dayrate in the low $150Ks.
    • Inpex extended its contract by about 15 months for an ESV semisubmersible at a lower dayrate in the mid $350Ks, plus ~$125K/day for capital upgrades and dayrates during shipyard stay and mobilizations; the contract is expected to end in September 2019.
    • Summing up, Fun Trading finds encouragement that ESV was able to secure some contracts recently despite terminations and slashed dayrates.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:27 PM | 9 Comments

  • Energy/Materials - Top Gainers / Losers as of 2:00 pm

    • Gainers: TRX +10%.
    • Losers: BCEI -11%. CIE -9%. IPI -8%. ZEUS -8%. CENX -8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:01 PM
  • WIT

    Wipro lower after earnings miss

    • Shares of Wipro (NYSE:WIT) are down 4% after missing on both lines of its FQ1 report.
    • Gross revenue $2.0B (+11% Y/Y).
    • Net income of $304M (-6%).
    • IT Services Segment Revenue was $1.93B (+7.6%).
    • Non-GAAP constant currency IT Services Segment revenue (+9.5%).
    • IT Services Segment profits of $345M (-3.0%).
    • Margin fell sharply by 190 bps to 17.8%.
    • The company expects Q2 revenue for IT services business to be in the range of $1.93-$1.95B, a growth of 0.01%-1.00% (Q/Q).
    • Previously: Wipro misses by $0.02, misses on revenue (July 19)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:56 PM
  • DB

    S&P closer to cut of Deutsche Bank credit rating

    • The agency lowers its credit outlook for Deustche Bank (DB -3.9%) to Negative from Stable, suggesting a rating cut could be in the offing in the near-future.
    • Low interest rates and sluggish client activity are challenges for all lenders, but "particularly unhelpful" for Deutsche as it tries to restructure. Now add Brexit to the mix, and the bank's plans get even more difficult to pull off.
    • For now, S&P keeps its BBB+ rating on Detusche's long-term unsecured debt. Moody's downgraded in May.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:29 PM
  • CMA

    Comerica higher as reserves fall, management talks cost cuts

    • Q2 net income of $104M of $0.58 per share vs. $135M and $0.73 one year ago. This year's Q2 result includes restructuring charges of $34M or $0.19 per share associated with the initial phase of management's efficiency and revenue initiative ("Gear up"), which is expected to boost pretax income by $230M by year-end 2018.
    • As part of "Gear up," the efficiency ratio is expected to decline to the low 60% range by the end of 2017, and be at or below 60% by year-end 2018.
    • As for energy loans, the bank set aside just $49M in provisions in Q2, down from $148M in Q1. Energy loans declined 11% in the quarter, but total loans increased 2%.
    • CMA +1.8%
    • Previously: Comerica beats by $0.08, misses on revenue (July 19)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:18 PM
  • VZ

    Moffett: Macro environment responsible for telecom success

    • The typical metrics that telecom investors examine may not matter as much to their holdings as a favorable macroeconomic environment, industry analyst Craig Moffett writes.
    • That's accounting for the price war as well as common bellwethers like average revenue per user, he says. In most industries, developments like telecom has seen in the past year (Verizon's (VZ -0.5%) recent moves to reset pricing; T-Mobile's (TMUS -0.3%) un-carrier promotions; aggressive phone financing revamps) would spur meaty debates about valuation and growth: "But telecom isn't most industries. It has now been a full decade since fundamentals were last a major part of the telco equity performance story (good or bad)."
    • Fundamentals may matter again soon, ahead of a new iPhone introduction (that could benefit T-Mobile and Sprint (S -3.9%) more than AT&T and Verizon), and AT&T's (T -0.2%) full integration of DirecTV finances.
    • But in the meantime, macro factors are still prevalent: "When interest rates are falling and the dollar is rising, the story appears to have been pretty straightforward, after all: Buy telecom."
     
     
     
     
    | 1:13 PM | 20 Comments

  • CHK

    Chesapeake, Tom Ward sued by shale owners for alleged conspiracy

    • Chesapeake Energy (CHK -1.7%) and former partner Tom Ward are being sued by investors who say the pair conspired to rig bids for drilling rights during the shale boom.
    • The lawsuit brought by Chisholm Partners and its investors, which accuses CHK and Ward of working together to artificially lower prices while Aubrey McClendon led CHK and Ward was CEO at SandRidge Energy, seeks at least $30M in damages.
    • The suit alleges that CHK and  SD between them illegally divided up the geographic area covering the Anadarko Basin Region in Kansas, and other states, and agreed not to compete and drive up prices.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:48 AM | 47 Comments
  • LNG

    Cheniere Energy's LNG export plant to shut in September for maintenance

    • Cheniere Energy's (LNG -2%) Sabine Pass liquefied natural gas export plant on the U.S. Gulf Coast will shut down for planned maintenance in September, Reuters reports.
    • The Louisiana plant, which began operations in February and has exported 17 cargoes so far, can produce ~4.5M metric tons/year of LNG from its one existing production line; the second LNG train at the plant is expected to enter service by the end of August.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:38 AM | 16 Comments
  • CBZ

    CBIZ gets the nod from Sidoti

    • Shares of CBIZ (CBZ +2.3%) track higher after Sidoti issues a Buy rating on the services stock.
    • Sidoti is the one of only two Wall Street firms covering CBIZ. The other is First Analysis which has an Equal Weight rating on the books.
    • CBIZ is up 11.4% YTD.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:33 AM
  • SCLN

    Dearth of white knights prompts SciClone to stay the course as independent firm; shares off 19%

    • Micro cap SciClone Pharmaceuticals (SCLN -19.4%) slumps on more than 50% higher volume in response to its announcement that is no longer in active discussions with potential acquirers and it intends, at least for now, to remain an independent company.
    • Based on a strategic review, the firm approached a number of potential suitors about a possible merger but failed to generate any interest in a transaction that would boost shareholder value.
    • The company expects to generate $158M - 163M in revenues this calendar year. Non-GAAP EPS should be $0.70 - 0.74. Q2 results will be released on August 9.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:32 AM

  • Healthcare - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 11:00 am

    • Gainers: SPHS +38%. CERU +15%. DRIO +12%. PULM +11%. HTGM +10%.
    • Losers: SCLN -18%. AEMD -14%. EVOK -10%. MRNS -10%. WVE -9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:02 AM
  • STLD

    Steel Dynamics -5% on "challenged" steel demand outlook

    • Steel Dynamics (STLD -4.9%) sinks despite beating Q2 earnings expectations and coming in a penny better than the upper end of its prior EPS guidance of $0.53-$0.57.
    • STLD says import levels are down 25% YTD but is seeing activity picking up a bit as prices have risen, although it does not expect imports to return to levels in late 2014-early 2015 which exploded the U.S. market.
    • STLD says there has been "steady underlying demand" for flat-rolled steel products and expects improved flat-rolled metal spreads in Q3, but "aside from the construction sector, long product steel demand is generally challenged, and selling values are under pressure from excess domestic production capability."
    • STLD also says that while it anticipates metal spread expansion for its long products group in Q3, lower shipments related to customers buying ahead could offset related margin gain.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:59 AM
  • GOV-OLD

    Government Properties Trust stung by downgrade

    • Government Properties Trust (GOV-OLD -3.6%) is an outlier to the downside among the office REITs after Jefferies downgrades to Underperform from Hold. The $17 price target compares to the current $23.33.
    • GOV has had a big run this year, up nearly 80% since mid-January.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:33 AM | 6 Comments
  • QUOT

    Quotient Technology CFO exiting; shares -5.8%

    • Quotient Technology (NYSE:QUOT) has slipped 5.8% after the news that its chief financial officer is departing for other opportunities.
    • Jennifer Ceran has resigned that post effective Aug. 9. Former CFO Mir Aamir, now the company's chief operating officer and president, will serve in the interim.
    • The company also said based on preliminary results, it expects to meet or exceed its guidance when it releases Q2 earnings after the close on Aug. 2, and it will affirm or increase full-year guidance.
    • The company plans a conference call for 4:30 p.m. that day.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:25 AM
  • GLOFY

    Ubisoft defense against Vivendi takeover getting foothold

    • Mounting a spirited defense against a takeover by Vivendi (OTCPK:VIVHY -1.3%), Ubisoft (OTCPK:UBSFY +3.9%) may be getting traction with investors with a case to pursue better returns on its own.
    • Shares of Ubisoft are up 4.9% in Paris to a 52-week high there.
    • Vivendi increased its stake in Ubisoft to more than 20% of capital today, and has already taken control of sibling company Gameloft (OTCPK:GLOFY), also run by the Guillemot family.
    • Ubisoft founder Yves Guillemot is pushing institutional shareholders to back the family's approach, which includes buying up more stock (the Guillemots hold 9% of capital and 15% of voting rights).
    • Vivendi says it's not pursuing a full takeover for at least six months, though it has asked for board seats.
    • Ubisoft reports its Q1 sales tomorrow, with eyes on the success of its recent release The Division.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:20 AM
  • GS

    Investors not yet buying Goldman beat

    • FICC revenue up 20% was a bright spot, but business in other units was sluggish, notably in investment banking, where revenue fell 11%, in part thanks to a slump in M&A business, but mostly due to a major drop in IPO business - equity issuance dropped 55%.
    • Both Nomura's Steven Chubak and Citi's Keith Horowitz remind Goldman has already had a nice run on the back of the post-Brexit bounce and earlier earnings reports from JPMorgan, Citi, and Bank of America (Goldman's ahead 10% in July), so perhaps today's pause shouldn't be a surprise.
    • Speaking on the earnings call, CFO Harvey Schwartz says client volume levels were down headed into Brexit, but hit peak activity following the shock vote. He doesn't expect Brexit to be a headwind to the bank's business.
    • WSJ blog
    • GS -0.5%
    • Previously: Trading revenue bounces back at Goldman, but conditions remain challenging (July 19)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:08 AM | 1 Comment
  • GES

    Guess in retreat after Piper Jaffray cut

    • Shares of Guess (GES -5.9%) are lower after Piper Jaffray expresses concerns on the retailer.
    • The investment firm sees bumps in the road for Guess in the near term, including U.S. traffic trends and managing a "bloated" level of inventory.
    • PJ lowers Guess to Underweight and tags its with a price target of $12 which stands below the 52-week low of $13.89.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:03 AM
  • MNGA

    MagneGas sees positive septic wastewater results

    • MagneGas (MNGA +55.7%) soars in early trade after announcing successful results from its recent testing of developmental wastewater sterilization equipment.
    • "We are steadily moving closer to actively entering this market," CEO Ermanno Santilli said. "In Florida alone, one third of all residents use a septic system for disposal of their wastewater."
     
     
     
     
    | 9:55 AM | 11 Comments
  • MTG

    MGIC Investment takes flight after big earnings beat

    • Though a real bull market for MGIC Investment (MTG +8.3%) awaits follow-through on the government's promise to cede more market share to private mortgage insurers, says BTIG's Mark Palmer, Q2's strong report should remind investors of the company's potential, particularly in light of the cheap valuation.
    • The results confirmed media reports from last week suggesting strong volumes in the PMI industry in Q2, he says.
    • Net written premiums of $250M exceeded his estimate of $241.3M, and revenues of $263.5M topped Palmer's already-bullish forecast of $260.1M.
    • Book value rose 7.1% to $7.37 per share - even with today's big gain, the stock (at $6.91 currently) still trades at a sizable discount.
    • Palmer reiterates his Buy rating and $12 price target.
    • Up in concert with MTIG are Radian (RDN +2.7%) and Essent Group (ESNT +1.1%).
    • Previously: MGIC Investment on the move after topping estimates (July 19)
     
     
     
     
    | 9:53 AM | 2 Comments
  • ZNDO

    Zalandro pops after updating on Q2

    • Shares of Zalandro (ZNDO) are soaring in Paris trading after the online retailer posted impressive preliminary Q2 results.
    • The company expects to report revenue growth of 24% to 26% to €909M to €924M. Adjusted EBIT of €68M to €88M is anticipated.
    • Zalandro was up 20.52% at last check.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:47 AM
  • NFLX

    Analysts and investors reset expectations on Netflix

    • Analysts are busy sizing up Netflix (NASDAQ:NFLX) after the company's Q2 tally of new subscribers fell short of expectations. Price hike concerns in the U.S. were a larger factor than some expected.
    • Most firms on Wall Street kept their previous rating on Netflix in place, while adjusting their price target: Citigroup (Neutral) PT to $106 from $92, Wedbush (Underperform) PT to $50 from $45, BMO Capital Markets (Hold) PT to $85 from $115, JPMorgan (Overweight) PT to $116 from $125, Credit Suisse (Neutral) PT to $122 from $119.
    • FBR chopped its price target to $90 and delivered some of the most biting commentary in its note to clients.
    • FBR on Netflix: "We heard Netflix's argument that the meaningful second-quarter sub miss was all due to greater-than-expected sensitivity of consumers to reports of an impending effective rate hike. But we cannot say we find that comforting. Instead, to us this suggests the loyalty of Netflix subscribers is thin."
    • Outside of Wall Street, Mark Cuban has a take. "I'm not worried about quarter to quarter fluctuations. They continue to dominate the content and consumer delivery for over the top," wrote the Dallas Mavericks owner.
    • Fresh Seeking Alpha articles on Netflix dive into the Q2 read, conference call commentary, and long-term outlook on the streamer.
    • Shares of Netflix are down 12.73% to $86.23 in early trading. The 52-week low on NFLX is $79.95.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:39 AM | 17 Comments
  • ECR

    Eclipse Resources raises FY 2016 production guidance

    • Eclipse Resources (NYSE:ECR) +4.5% premarket after reporting that Q2 production averaged 236.1M cfe/day (71% natural gas, 19% natural gas liquids, 10% oil), +19% Y/Y, +17% Q/Q and 18% above previously issued guidance.
    • For FY 2016, ECR raises its production guidance by ~7% to 220M-225M cfe/day.
    • Since resuming operations in Q2, ECR says it has drilled two net operated Utica Shale wells and is drilling its third well in the dry gas portion of its Utica Shale acreage.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:14 AM | 3 Comments
  • DARE

    Cerulean's CRLX101 Fast Track'd for certain platinum-resistant cancers; shares up 11% premarket

    • Thinly traded nano cap Cerulean Pharma (CERU) is up 11% premarket on increased volume in response to its announcement that the FDA has designated its lead nanoparticle-drug conjugate, Phase 1/2-stage CRLX101, for Fast Track review for the treatment of platinum-resistant ovarian, fallopian tube or primary peritoneal cancer.
    • Fast Track status provides for more frequent interactions with the FDA review team and a rolling review of the New Drug Application (NDA).
     
     
     
     
    | 9:14 AM

  • Premarket Gainers / Losers as of 9:10 am

    • Gainers: HDSN +39%. FELP +14%. SYPR +12%. CERU +10%. PLUG +10%. ARNA +9%. VMW +9%. ZIOP +8%. MTG +8%.
    • Losers: SMCI -25%. NFLX -14%. BLDP -7%. ERIC -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:14 AM
  • DEO

    Diageo looks for pension relief

    • Diageo (NYSE:DEO) says it is working with employee groups to lower costs tied to a legacy pension plan.
    • The legacy pension plan is a remnant from the merger of Guinness and Grand Metropolitan.
    • Just.drinks.com estimates the plan in question costs Diageo £43M ($57M).
    • Diageo ADRs are down 1.69% in premarket trading.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:10 AM
  • SAVE

    Spirit Airlines lower after Q2 update

    • Spirit Airlines (NASDAQ:SAVE) updates guidance in an update to investors.
    • Revenue per available seat mile was down 14.3% Y/Y during the quarter to fall on the low end of the company's original guidance. Fare pressure played in to the RASM weakness.
    • Capacity was up 23.1% in Q2.
    • The company says it recorded adjusted operating margin of approximately 22%. Adjusted cost per available seat mile decreased 8% vs. initial guidance for a drop of 5%.
    • Spirit Airlines Investor Update (.pdf)
    • SAVE -5.46% premarket to $45.20.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:04 AM | 8 Comments
  • GPC

    Genuine Parts down on earnings miss

    • Genuine Parts (NYSE:GPC) reports foreign exchange negatively impacted sales by 1% in Q2.
    • Acquisition contributed 2 percentage point of growth to the revenue in the quarter.
    • Segment sales: Automotive: $2.09B (-0.7%); Industrial: $1.17B (-1.7%); Office Products: $481.61M (+0.8%); Electrical/Electronic Materials: $184.51M (-5.2%).
    • Gross margin rate constant Y/Y at 29.9%.
    • FY2016 Guidance: Sales: +1% to +2%; Diluted EPS: $4.70 to $4.75.
    • GPC -5.64% premarket.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:02 AM | 5 Comments
  • SN

    Sanchez Energy's Q2 production exceeds high end of guidance

    • Sanchez Energy (NYSE:SN) +4.5% premarket after reporting Q2 production of ~5.1M boe, or ~55.9K boe/day, a 4% Y/Y increase that also exceeded the high end of the company's guidance by more than 7%.
    • SN says the average cost per well during the quarter was $3.3M, with results of some wells coming in below $3M.
    • SN says it brought 13 wells on-line at Catarina during Q2, with wells drilled and completed so far in Catarina's South-Central region having average 30-day initial production rates of ~1,350 boe/day.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:58 AM
  • GFI

    Gold Fields expects big H1 earnings boost

    • Gold Fields (NYSE:GFI) +2.3% premarket after saying it expects H1 earnings to surge, citing the recovery in the gold price and lower operating costs helped by a weaker rand.
    • GFI says it expects to report on Aug. 18 that its basic EPS for the period was US$0.14, up from zero in its prior interim period, with headline EPS of US$0.16 vs. US$0.01 in the prior-year period.
    • GFI expects H1 attributable gold equivalent production of 1.04M oz., +0.7% Y/Y, with all-in sustaining costs of production at $992/oz., -8.4% Y/Y; for Q2, GFI sees attributable equivalent production of 529K oz., +2.7% Y/Y, with AISC of $1,023/oz., +6.4% Y/Y.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:39 AM | 2 Comments
  • ZIOP

    Patient death in ZIOPHARM's early-stage brain tumor trial not related to study drug; shares up 9% premarket

    • In a statement, ZIOPHARM (NASDAQ:ZIOP) says the recent patient death from intracranial hemorrhage in its Phase 1 clinical trial assessing Ad-RTS-hIL-12 + orally administered veledimex in progressive glioblastoma or grade III malignant glioma was determined to be unrelated to the study drug.
    • Enrollment remains open. The company will provide further updates when appropriate. Longer-term survival data will be released later this year.
    • Shares are up 9% premarket on increased volume.
    • Previously: Patient deaths in Ziopharm's IL-12 brain tumor trial sink shares, down 22% premarket (July 15)
     
     
     
     
    | 8:38 AM | 7 Comments
  • KSU

    More on Kansas City Southern's Q2

    • Kansas City Southern (NYSE:KSU) reports operating margin rate rose 680 bps to 38.7% in Q2.

    Monsanto rejects Bayer buyout bid as insufficient

    • Monsanto (NYSE:MON) -1.6% premarket after rejecting Bayer’s revised takeover proposal is "financially inadequate and insufficient to ensure deal certainty."
